awd_titl_txt: DIRECT ELECTRICAL MODULATION OF LIGHT EMISSION AT SUB-LIFETIME  SCALES
awd_abstract_narration:
The objective of this program is to develop a new architecture for high-speed phosphorescent devices based on the dynamic control of light emission at sub-lifetime speeds. Direct, sub-lifetime modulation of light emission promises to enable the development of compact, high-speed phosphorescent devices. Such devices would have a transformative impact on communication, display, and lighting technologies as well as applications in biological and chemical sensing. The educational aspects include development of a laboratory-intensive Photonics course that will emphasize the design of dynamic and reconfigurable optical systems; development of a new Advanced Spectroscopy Workshop for researchers, students, and teachers in Rhode Island; expansion of the SearchLight Project to help promote the new Design Workshop maker space in the Laboratory for Engineering, especially to train and support local community members.


The intellectual significance is centered on the investigation of a new method for modulating the slowly decaying emitters that form the basis for many modern optoelectronic devices. Rather than modulating the excited state population, the goal is to modify the local optical environment and directly modulate emission rates into different modes within the excited state lifetime.  The approach involves a program to demonstrate an electrically-modulated light emitting device based upon the sub-lifetime modulation of erbium emission near the telecom-wavelength of 1550 nm.  In addition, a new material platform for high-speed modulation based on leveraging the electronic and vibronic emission from transition-metal phosphors will be investigated. This program will enhance the understanding of dynamic processes in both light emitting and phase change materials.

por.por_cntn:
The term “phosphorescence” is generally used to describe the slowly decaying luminescence associated with parity-forbidden and/or spin-forbidden optical transitions. Despite their “slow” and “forbidden” nature, phosphors play an important role in a range of modern device technologies from displays and lighting to lasers, sensors, and telecommunication. Interestingly, the same electronic structure that makes lanthanide and transition-metal phosphors slow emitters often helps ensure that they are highly efficient. Nevertheless, their slow radiative decay rate is generally perceived as a technological limit for high-speed photonic devices. 

Intellectual Merit: This research program demonstrated a fundamentally new method to transform “slow” phosphorescent emitters into high-speed integrated light sources without degrading their high quantum efficiency. Rather than modulating the excited state population, this approach modifies the local optical environment using phase-change materials, and thus can directly modulate emission at sub-lifetime speeds. For example, leveraging the insulator-to-metal transition of vanadium dioxide, we demonstrated direct modulation of 1.55 micron erbium light emission that was three orders of magnitude faster than the excited state lifetime. We also explored how these methods could be extended to a range of device architectures (e.g., high-index-contrast grating systems), emitter systems (including lanthanide and transition-metal ions), and phase-change materials (such as germanium-antimony-tellurium, which is also known as GeSbTe or GST). In addition to work on photonic devices, this project advanced basic science related to optical materials. For example, this program supported the development of group theoretic methods to systematically calculate the electronic structure and magnetic dipole emission rates of transition-metal dopants in different crystallographic point groups, which in turn helped extend the library of potential phosphorescent materials for high-speed modulation across the visible and near-infrared spectrum.

Broad Impacts: Modulation is a cornerstone of optical communication, and as such, sub-lifetime modulation of phosphorescent emission at telecommunication wavelengths has shown how phase-change materials can enable fundamentally new photonic device designs. Despite their wide-spread use in amplifiers, displays, lasers, and lighting (e.g. inorganic LEDs), phosphorescent emitters have been considered impractical for high speed applications because of their intrinsically long lifetimes. Our results demonstrated a simple way to circumvent this limitation and modulate their emission at high speeds. Unlike III-V materials, phosphorescent emitters can be easily integrated on all kinds of nanoscale, silicon-compatible devices. Such devices would have direct applications at the interface of communication, display, and lighting technologies as well as in biological and chemical sensing. In addition to disseminating our work through academic conferences and journals, these results were also shared through presentations at industrial research facilities (e.g., Osram Sylvania’s Central Research & Service Laboratory and Raytheon BBN Technologies) as well as industry forums (such as the Global Phosphor Summit). In terms of education and outreach, this program also supported: the development of three courses at Brown on photonic system design, experimental automation, and the application of machine learning to experimental science; collaboration with the Providence Children’s Museum on an LED sculpture exhibit; and the Zia lab’s engagement with the Providence Public School District through the Brown Elementary Afterschool Mentoring program at William D’Abate Elementary School, the Spira Engineering Camp at Brown for local high school students, and the annual Vartan Gregorian Science Conference.
